whenToCite.facts: Cite all factual claims, data points, and verifiable information
whenToCite.statistics: Cite all statistics, numbers, percentages, and quantitative data
whenToCite.quotes: Cite all direct quotes, paraphrased quotes, and attributed statements
whenToCite.claims: Cite all claims, assertions, and statements of fact
whenToCite.definitions: Cite all definitions, explanations of terms, and conceptual descriptions
whenToCite.dates: Cite all dates, timeframes, and temporal information
whenToCite.locations: Cite all geographic locations, places, and spatial information
whenToCite.names: Cite all proper names, organizations, and entities when first mentioned
whenToCite.processes: Cite all descriptions of processes, procedures, and methodologies
whenToCite.comparisons: Cite all comparisons, contrasts, and relative statements

documentCitations.description: Use for citations from document excerpts
rules: Use the exact label from the 'Relevant Document Excerpts' section
Number corresponds to the order in the context
No URL needed for document citations
Can use [Document Name] if a document name is provided

documentCitationsWithUrl.description: Use when document has a URL in the context
rules: Use document name if provided in context
Include document://id URL format
Make the link clickable

webCitations.description: Use for citations from web search results
rules: Use the exact label from the 'Web Search Results' section
ALWAYS include the full URL in parentheses
URL must match the URL from the web search results
Make the link clickable using markdown format

webCitationsWithTitle.description: Use when web source has a descriptive title
rules: Use descriptive title if provided in context
Always include full URL
Title should be concise and descriptive

inline.description: Citations should be placed inline within sentences
examples: Machine learning is a subset of AI [Document 1] that enables systems to learn from data.
According to [Web Source 1](https://example.com), the technology has advanced significantly.
The study found that 85% of participants [Web Source 2](https://example.com/study) preferred the new approach.
rules: Place citation immediately after the fact or claim
Citations should flow naturally within the sentence
Avoid placing all citations at the end of paragraphs

sentenceStart.description: Citations can start sentences when appropriate
examples: [Document 1] According to the policy, remote work is allowed up to three days per week.
[Web Source 1](https://example.com) The latest research shows significant improvements in accuracy.
rules: Use when the entire sentence is from one source
Citation should come before the statement

sentenceEnd.description: Citations can end sentences when appropriate
examples: The capital of France is Paris [Web Source 1](https://example.com/france).
Neural networks use backpropagation for training [Document 2].
rules: Use when the entire sentence is from one source
Citation should come after the statement

factualStatement.example: The population of Tokyo is approximately 14 million people [Web Source 1](https://example.com/tokyo-population).
factualStatement.explanation: Cite factual information with the source immediately after the fact

statisticalData.example: According to the study [Web Source 2](https://example.com/study), 72% of users prefer mobile apps over desktop applications.
statisticalData.explanation: Cite statistics with the source, preferably at the start or after the number

directQuote.example: As stated in the report [Document 1], 'The implementation was successful in 95% of cases.'
directQuote.explanation: Cite quotes with the source, using quotation marks for direct quotes

paraphrasedQuote.example: The expert explained [Web Source 3](https://example.com/expert) that the process requires careful planning and execution.
paraphrasedQuote.explanation: Cite paraphrased quotes with the source

definition.example: Machine learning [Document 2] is a method of data analysis that automates analytical model building.
definition.explanation: Cite definitions with the source immediately after the term

processDescription.example: The deployment process involves several steps [Document 3]: first, prepare the environment; second, configure the settings; and third, run the deployment script.
processDescription.explanation: Cite process descriptions with the source

comparison.example: Supervised learning uses labeled data [Web Source 4](https://example.com/supervised), while unsupervised learning works with unlabeled data [Web Source 5](https://example.com/unsupervised).
comparison.explanation: Cite each part of a comparison with its respective source

multipleFacts.example: The company reported revenue of $10 million [Web Source 6](https://example.com/revenue) and plans to expand to five new markets [Document 4] by the end of the year.
multipleFacts.explanation: Cite each fact separately when they come from different sources

singleSourceMultipleFacts.example: The research study [Web Source 7](https://example.com/research) found that user satisfaction increased by 30% and response times decreased by 40%.
singleSourceMultipleFacts.explanation: When multiple facts come from the same source, cite once at the end or after the first fact

mandatory: EVERY factual statement MUST have a citation
EVERY statistic MUST have a citation
EVERY quote MUST have a citation
EVERY claim MUST have a citation
NO information should be presented without a source
formatting: Use markdown link format: [text](URL) for web sources
Use [Document N] format for document sources
URLs must be complete and valid
Never use plain text for citations
placement: Place citations immediately after the fact or claim
Citations should flow naturally within sentences
Avoid clustering all citations at paragraph end
Each sentence with facts should have citations
Multiple facts from same source can share one citation
validation: Every citation must reference a source from the provided context
Document citations must match labels in 'Relevant Document Excerpts'
Web citations must match labels and URLs in 'Web Search Results'
URLs must be exact matches from the context
No citations to sources not provided in context

missingCitations.correct: Always include citations for all factual information

incorrectFormat.correct: Use proper markdown format: [text](URL) for web, [Document N] for documents

wrongUrl.correct: Use exact URLs from the web search results context

missingUrl.correct: ALWAYS include full URL in parentheses for web sources

citationClustering.mistake: Placing all citations at the end of paragraphs
citationClustering.correct: Place citations inline, immediately after each fact

example.wrong: The population is 14 million. The city covers 2,000 km². [Web Source 1]
example.correct: The population is 14 million [Web Source 1](https://example.com/pop). The city covers 2,000 km² [Web Source 2](https://example.com/area).

citationToNonExistentSource.mistake: Citing sources not in the provided context
citationToNonExistentSource.correct: Only cite sources that are explicitly provided in the context

example.correct: Use only sources numbered 1-5 as provided in context
